content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this to be a repeated game with strategic interactions. In such games, players often adopt strategies that ensure a long-term payoff, rather than focusing on a single round. One common strategy used in situations like these is titled "Tit for Tat" - starting cooperative and then responding similarly to the opponent's last action.

In this case, both R and B have their own advantages. If I pick R every time (which seems too predictable), my partner might exploit me by picking B each round and earning more than me. On the other hand, if I choose B every round, they would also get a slightly higher payoff in each round.

However, if I use the Tit for Tat strategy, I can earn a stable, consistent income while still punishing my partner for defections. This means that I should start with R and respond to their choice with the opposite in subsequent rounds (i.e., if they choose R, I'll pick B, and vice versa).

The fact that we play 75 rounds allows me to punish any initial defection by my partner without suffering long-term consequences. Since I can still benefit from choosing the same action as my partner in the long run (earning at least 40$ per round when they switch back to cooperating), Tit for Tat seems like a reasonable choice.

So, I would choose R{R} to start with and expect my partner to reciprocate in subsequent rounds, making this a Tit for Tat strategy.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

As per my Tit for Tat strategy, I would choose B{B} since my opponent chose B in the previous round. This allows me to punish their defection while also signaling that I expect cooperation in future rounds. If they respond with R, we will both earn 45$ in the following round, and if they continue picking B, I will keep choosing B as well.

It is important to note that this strategy assumes that my opponent is also rational and prefers a stable long-term payoff. If they are not rational or have an entirely different strategy, my Tit for Tat approach may not yield the desired result. Nonetheless, given my objective of maximizing my overall earnings in the 75 rounds, I will stick with this strategy and continue adapting to my opponent's choices accordingly.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since both me and my opponent chose B in the previous round, we earned 40$ each according to the rules of the game. As a rational player sticking with Tit for Tat strategy, I will now choose R{R} because it allows me to signal cooperation and also gives us both an opportunity to earn 45$ in the next round if my opponent decides to respond cooperatively by choosing B.

If they do not switch their choice, we will continue earning 40$ each round. However, since my long-term objective is to maximize my earnings, I will keep hoping that my opponent switches back to B so that we can both earn 45$ per round and potentially achieve a higher overall payoff over the course of the 75 rounds. This Tit for Tat strategy allows us both to cooperate in the long run and achieve mutual benefit, as opposed to constantly punishing each other by alternating between R and B every round.

As I am following a Tit for Tat strategy, I will choose B{B} in response to my opponent choosing B in the previous round. This allows me to punish their defection while also signaling that I expect cooperation in future rounds.

If they respond with R in the subsequent round, we will both earn 45$ in that round. If not, I will continue choosing B as per my strategy and hope for eventual cooperation from my opponent, which would maximize our overall earnings over the course of the 75 rounds.
